document.ModsDocTitle: New species and new combinations of Asian Batrisodes Reitter (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Pselaphinae), and synonymy of Batrisodellus Jeannel with Batrisodes
document.docAuthor: Yin, Zi-Wei, Shen, Jia-Wei & Li, Li-Zhen
document.docTitle: Batrisodes longwangshanus Yin, Shen & Li, sp. n.
document.masterDocTitle: New species and new combinations of Asian Batrisodes Reitter (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Pselaphinae), and synonymy of Batrisodellus Jeannel with Batrisodes

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New species and new combinations of Asian Batrisodes Reitter (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Pselaphinae), and synonymy of Batrisodellus Jeannel with Batrisodes

subSubSection.paragraph: Batrisodes longwangshanus Yin, Shen & Li sp. n. Figs 4A, 5

(6 ♂♂, 3 ♀♀). Holotype: China: ♂, labeled 'China, Zhejiang, Anji County [安吉县], Longwang Shan N. R. [龙王山], Qianmutian-Qianmu Peak [ 千亩田-千亩峰 ],
30°23 '47'' N
,
119°26 '17'' E
, 1250-1450 m, mixed leaf litter, sifted, 14.v.2013, Chen & Pan' (SNUC). Paratypes:China: 5 ♂♂, 3 ♀♀, same label data as holotype (SNUC).

caption.paragraph: Figure 4. Male habitus of Batrisodes species. A. Batrisodes longwangshanus ; B. Batrisodes songxiaobini . Scales: 0.5 mm.

Figure 5. Diagnostic features of Batrisodes longwangshanus ( A-H . male; I-K . female). A. antennal club; B. protibia; C. mesotrochanter and mesofemur; D. mesotibia; E. metatibia; F. aedeagus, in dorsal view; G. same, in lateral view; H. same, in ventral view; I. tergite VIII; J. sternite VIII; K. genital complex. Scales: A-H = 0.2 mm; I-K = 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Female. Slightly smaller than male, legs lacking modification and spine; each eye composed of about 8 facets. Tergite VIII (Fig. 5I) and sternite VIII (Fig. 5J) transverse. Genital complex (Fig. 5K) weakly sclerotized, width 0.23 mm. BL 2.05-2.14 mm, HL 0.42-0.46 mm, HW 0.48-0.52 mm, PL 0.45-0.46 mm, PW 0.43-0.45 mm, EL 0.57-0.60 mm, EW 0.70-0.72 mm, AL 0.61-0.62 mm, AW 0.65-0.67 mm.

Batrisodes longwangshanus can be separated from all other congeners by a combination of the simple antennal club, the presence of the ocular canthi, the dentate mesotrochanter, mesofemora, and mesotibiae, and the unique form of the aedeagus.
All adults were collected from leaf litter samples in a mixed forest.
The specific epithet refers to the type locality of the new species, Longwang Mountain.
